{"role":"user","content":"The following is the commit files that have changed: [ { "sha": "7933e747cc949b686d48d5f359d3e037db6124b2", "filename": "docs/architecture/id-protection-guide-analyze.md", "status": "modified", "additions": 6, "deletions": 4, "changes": 10, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/7faf8d961df7559fb440fae757f2cd5554f29fde/docs%2Farchitecture%2Fid-protection-guide-analyze.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/7faf8d961df7559fb440fae757f2cd5554f29fde/docs%2Farchitecture%2Fid-protection-guide-analyze.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Farchitecture%2Fid-protection-guide-analyze.md?ref=7faf8d961df7559fb440fae757f2cd5554f29fde", "patch": "@@ -102,7 +102,7 @@ Screenshot of the **KQL mode** option.\n \r\n ## Identify risky users\r\n \r\n-This section and the following sections illustrate how to analyze risk with Azure Monitor. Risk users have one or more risky sign-ins, or other risky actions\r\n+This section and the following sections illustrate how to analyze risk with Azure Monitor. Risky users have one or more risky sign-ins, or other risky actions\r\n \r\n 1. Run the query to summarize the count by **UserDisplayName**.\r\n 2. Add a time range in **DetectedDateTime < ago()**. \r\n@@ -141,7 +141,7 @@ AADUserRiskEvents\n | summarize count()by RiskEventType \r\n ```\r\n \r\n-While reviewing risk types, pay attention to large volumes. In the following screenshot, there are flagged risk events, most are related to:\r\n+While reviewing risk types, pay attention to large volumes. In the following example, there are several flagged risk events. Most are related to:\r\n \r\n * **UnfamiliarFeatures** - Detect unfamiliar sign-in properties for a user\r\n * Enforce session controls such as sign-in frequency, application restrictions, and persistent browser controls\r\n@@ -169,15 +169,15 @@ AADUserRiskEvents\n | summarize count()by RiskLevel \r\n ```\r\n \r\n-In the following screenshot, three detections are high-risk. We recommend a minimum-baseline Conditional Access policy that requires secure password change, or that blocks high-risk users. \r\n+In the following screenshot, there are many total detections, but only three detections are high-risk. Filtering by sensitivity—such as low, medium, or high risk—is an effective way to isolate the most critical issues. By focusing on high-risk detections first, you can reduce noise and address the most important threats. For these cases, we recommend implementing at least a baseline Conditional Access policy that enforces a secure password change for high-risk users.\r\n \r\n ![Screenshot of query results that show three high-risk users.](./media/id-protection-guide-analyze/three-high.png)\r\n \r\n Learn more about access control decisions: [What is Conditional Access?](/azure/data-explorer/security-conditional-access)\r\n \r\n ## Get started with Azure Monitor Logs reference tables\r\n \r\n-To help you get started, see and learn more about Azure Monitor Log reference tables for Microsoft Entra ID Protection. The following links go to a list of tables by table name. Use logs generated by identity protection for user risk events, risky users, Service Principal risk events, risky Service Principals, and more.\r\n+To get started, explore the Azure Monitor log reference tables for Microsoft Entra ID Protection. The links below provide a list of tables by name. These logs capture key insights, including user risk events, risky users, Service Principal risk events, and risky Service Principals, among others.\r\n \r\n * [AADUserRiskEvents](/azure/azure-monitor/reference/tables/aaduserriskevents)\r\n * [AADRiskyUsers](/azure/azure-monitor/reference/tables/aadriskyusers)\r\n@@ -258,6 +258,8 @@ To help you get started, see and learn more about Azure Monitor Log reference ta\n \r\n \r\n \r\n+\r\n+\r\n \r\n \r\n \r" }, { "sha": "5544b01102a89c678dfe830fd473356a946ba382", "filename": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/7faf8d961df7559fb440fae757f2cd5554f29fde/docs%2Fidentity%2Fauthentication%2Fhow-to-plan-password-scramble-phishing-resistant-passwordless-authentication.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/7faf8d961df7559fb440fae757f2cd5554f29fde/docs%2Fidentity%2Fauthentication%2Fhow-to-plan-password-scramble-phishing-resistant-passwordless-authentication.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Fauthentication%2Fhow-to-plan-password-scramble-phishing-resistant-passwordless-authentication.md?ref=7faf8d961df7559fb440fae757f2cd5554f29fde", "patch": "@@ -1,28 +1,29 @@\n ---\n title: Remove Passwords from Microsoft Entra ID\n-description: Password scrambling guidance to deploy passwordless and phishing-resistant authentication for organizations that use Microsoft Entra ID.\n+description: Removing password usage from Entra through Password scrambling to deploy passwordless and phishing-resistant authentication for organizations that use Microsoft Entra ID.\n \n ms.service: entra-id \n ms.subservice: authentication\n ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 10/03/2025\n+ms.date: 10/24/2025\n \n ms.author: justinha\n-author: mepples21\n+author: sipower\n manager: dougeby\n-ms.reviewer: miepping\n+ms.reviewer: sipower\n \n ms.collection: M365-identity-device-management\n # Customer intent: As an identity administrator, I want to understand how to plan phishing-resistant and passwordless authentication deployment in Microsoft Entra ID\n \n ---\n \n-# Plan to remove passwords from Microsoft Entra ID\n+# Remove password usage from Microsoft Entra ID\n \n Passwords are one of the least secure authentication methods available. They are vulnerable to a wide range of threats—including phishing, credential stuffing, brute-force attacks, and social engineering. To realize the benefits of passwordless authentication in Microsoft Entra ID, you must ensure passwords are no longer available as a sign-in option in your tenant.\n \n-Password scrambling ensures that users can't authenticate using passwords. It forces them to use more secure passwordless credentials like Windows Hello for Business, FIDO2 security keys, or Microsoft Authenticator. This article provides guidance about how to scramble passwords for both hybrid users who are synced from on-premises Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) and cloud-only users in Microsoft Entra ID.\n- \n+Password scrambling ensures that users can't authenticate by using passwords. It forces them to use more secure phishing-resistant passwordless credentials, like Windows Hello for Business, FIDO2 security keys, or passkey in Microsoft Authenticator. Because there's no known reference of the password after scrambling, it reduces the attack surface for bad actors.\n+\n+This article provides guidance about how to scramble passwords for both hybrid users who are synced from on-premises Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) and cloud-only users in Microsoft Entra ID.\n \n ## Prerequisites\n \n@@ -32,24 +33,18 @@ Password scrambling ensures that users can't authenticate using passwords. It fo\n \n Organizations with users synced from on-premises AD DS to Microsoft Entra ID should scramble user passwords in the on-premises environment, as on-premises is the source of authority for synced user accounts and their passwords. If your organization uses [cloud authentication](~/identity/hybrid/connect/choose-ad-authn.md) and syncs password hashes to Microsoft Entra ID, then these scrambled passwords are also synced to the cloud. The sync process ensures that users aren't aware of their passwords in either on-premises or the cloud, preventing their use and driving users towards using more secure phishing-resistant passwordless credentials.\n \n-### Option 1: Scramble on-premises user passwords with Smart Card Required for Interactive Logon (SCRIL)\n-\n-Scrambling user passwords with the Smart Card Required for Interactive Logon (SCRIL) setting is the recommended method for scrambling user passwords on-premises because it's a natively available option in AD DS. When SCRIL is enabled on a user object, the user’s AD DS password is randomized by the domain controller to a value no one knows. The user has to enroll and then must authenticate to the AD DS domain by using a smart card or Windows Hello for Business. With password hash synchronization enabled, this AD DS password hash is also synced with Microsoft Entra ID.\n+## Scramble on-premises user passwords with a scripted random value\n \n-The Smart Card Required for Interactive Logon setting can be configured using the Active Directory Users and Computers tool. The following sample PowerShell script can be used to enable the setting programmatically, including for many users at once. Modify the **samAccountName** variable of the script to match your environment, and then run it in a PowerShell session. Use the credentials of an admin account with appropriate permissions in on-premises AD.\n+In Active Directory, it is not possible to remove a password attribute from a user account. Therefore to prevent usage of the password you can scramble the password periodically.\n \n-```PowerShell\n-$samAccountName = \n+If you have legacy applications that still require a password for authentication, users can continue to use self-service password reset (SSPR) to set their password to a known state to access these apps for a period of time, until their password is scrambled again.\n \n-Import-Module ActiveDirectory\n-Set-ADUser -Identity $samAccountName -SmartcardLogonRequired $true\n-```\n+You can use the following script to routinely scramble any passwords that users reset back to a known state.\n \n-### Option 2: Scramble on-premises user passwords with a scripted random value\n+The script allows you to scramble a user's password in your AD DS domain. It generates a random password of 64 characters and sets it for the user specified in the variable name $samAccountName. You must modify the $samAccountName variable in the script to target the appropriate user. Use the credentials of an admin account with appropriate permissions in on-premises AD DS.\n \n-If you don't want to use Smart Card Required for Interactive Logon (SCRIL), another approach can be to scramble the password with a script. If users need to recover their passwords to access legacy apps, use a script to scramble the password. Run the script routinely to scramble any passwords that users reset back to a known state.\n-\n-The following sample PowerShell script generates a random password of 64 characters and sets it for the user specified in the variable name **$samAccountName** against on-premises AD DS domain. Modify the **$samAccountName** variable of the script to match your environment, and then run it in a PowerShell session. Use the credentials of an admin account with appropriate permissions in on-premises AD DS.\n+> [!CAUTION]\n+> Execute the script only from a secure and trusted environment, and ensure that the script isn't logged. Treat the host where the script is executed as a privileged host, with the same level of security as a domain controller.\n \n ```PowerShell\n $samAccountName = \n@@ -78,8 +73,8 @@ $NewPassword = ConvertTo-SecureString -String (Generate-RandomPassword) -AsPlain\n Set-ADAccountPassword -Identity $samAccountName -NewPassword $NewPassword -Reset\n ```\n \n-> [!CAUTION]\n-> Execute the script only from a secure and trusted environment, and ensure that the script isn't logged. Treat the host where the script is executed as a privileged host, with the same level of security as a domain controller.\n+> [!Note]\n+> If your password scrambling script runs less frequently than your current password age policy, then you should consider increasing password age to be greater than this frequency, or setting password age to 0, which disables password expiration.\n \n ## Randomize passwords for cloud user accounts in Microsoft Entra ID\n " }, { "sha": "b488cc7138e27dcefed3509cbafd6c666d160b22", "filename": "docs/identity/hybrid/connect/how-to-connect-health-agent-install.md", "status": "modified", "additions": 3, "deletions": 3, "changes": 6, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/7faf8d961df7559fb440fae757f2cd5554f29fde/docs%2Fidentity%2Fhybrid%2Fconnect%2Fhow-to-connect-health-agent-install.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/7faf8d961df7559fb440fae757f2cd5554f29fde/docs%2Fidentity%2Fhybrid%2Fconnect%2Fhow-to-connect-health-agent-install.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Fhybrid%2Fconnect%2Fhow-to-connect-health-agent-install.md?ref=7faf8d961df7559fb440fae757f2cd5554f29fde", "patch": "@@ -27,7 +27,7 @@ The following table lists requirements for using Microsoft Entra Connect Health:\n | Requirement | Description |\n | --- | --- |\n | You have a Microsoft Entra ID P1 or P2 subscription. |Microsoft Entra Connect Health is a feature of Microsoft Entra ID P1 or P2. For more information, see [Sign up for Microsoft Entra ID P1 or P2](~/fundamentals/get-started-premium.md).

To start a free 30-day trial, see [Start a trial](https://azure.microsoft.com/trial/get-started-active-directory/). |\n-| You're a Global Administrator in Microsoft Entra ID. |Currently, only Global Administrator accounts can install and configure health agents. .

By using Azure role-based access control (Azure RBAC), you can allow other users in your organization to access Microsoft Entra Connect Health. For more information, see [Azure RBAC for Microsoft Entra Connect Health](how-to-connect-health-operations.md#manage-access-with-azure-rbac).

**Important**: Use a work or school account to install the agents. You can't use a Microsoft account to install the agents. For more information, see [Sign up for Azure as an organization](~/fundamentals/sign-up-organization.md). |\n+| You're either a [Global Administrator](../../role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#global-administrator) or a [Hybrid Identity Administrator](../../role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#hybrid-identity-administrator) in Microsoft Entra ID. | By using Azure role-based access control (Azure RBAC), you can allow other users in your organization to access Microsoft Entra Connect Health. For more information, see [Azure RBAC for Microsoft Entra Connect Health](how-to-connect-health-operations.md#manage-access-with-azure-rbac).

**Important**: Use a work or school account to install the agents. You can't use a Microsoft account to install the agents. For more information, see [Sign up for Azure as an organization](~/fundamentals/sign-up-organization.md). |\n | The Microsoft Entra Connect Health agent is installed on each targeted server. | Health agents must be installed and configured on targeted servers so that they can receive data and provide monitoring and analytics capabilities.

For example, to get data from your Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS) infrastructure, you must install the agent on the AD FS server and on the Web Application Proxy server. Similarly, to get data from your on-premises AD Domain Services infrastructure, you must install the agent on the domain controllers. |\n | The Azure service endpoints have outbound connectivity. | During installation and runtime, the agent requires connectivity to Microsoft Entra Connect Health service endpoints. If firewalls block outbound connectivity, add the [outbound connectivity endpoints](how-to-connect-health-agent-install.md#outbound-connectivity-to-azure-service-endpoints) to an allowlist. |\n |Outbound connectivity is based on IP addresses. | For information about firewall filtering based on IP addresses, see [Azure IP ranges](https://www.microsoft.com/download/details.aspx?id=56519).|\n@@ -113,7 +113,7 @@ The command takes following parameters:\n - `AttributeFiltering`: `$true` (default) if Microsoft Entra Connect isn't syncing the default attribute set and has been customized to use a filtered attribute set. Otherwise, use `$false`.\n - `StagingMode`: `$false` (default) if the Microsoft Entra Connect server is *not* in staging mode. If the server is configured to be in staging mode, use `$true`. You can determine if the server is in staging mode with `(Get-ADSyncScheduler).StagingModeEnabled`.\n \n-When you're prompted for authentication, use the same Global Administrator account (such as `admin@domain.onmicrosoft.com`) that you used to configure Microsoft Entra Connect.\n+When you're prompted for authentication, use the same Global Administrator or Hybrid Identity Administrator account (such as `admin@domain.onmicrosoft.com`) that you used to configure Microsoft Entra Connect.\n \n \n \n@@ -186,7 +186,7 @@ These commands accept `Credential` as a parameter to complete the registration n\n \n - You can capture `Credential` in a PowerShell variable that's passed as a parameter.\n - You can provide any Microsoft Entra identity that has permissions to register the agents, and which does *not* have multifactor authentication enabled.\n-- By default, Global Administrators have permissions to register the agents. You can also allow less-privileged identities to do this step. For more information, see [Azure RBAC](how-to-connect-health-operations.md#manage-access-with-azure-rbac).\n+- By default, Global Administrators and Hybrid Identity Administrators have permissions to register the agents. You can also allow less-privileged identities to do this step. For more information, see [Azure RBAC](how-to-connect-health-operations.md#manage-access-with-azure-rbac).\n \n ```powershell\n $cred = Get-Credential" }, { "sha": "5862937af001cf0b9cdfd8329e99646cd65d0f7a", "filename": "docs/identity/users/licensing-service-plan-reference.md", "status": "modified", "additions": 6, "deletions": 3, "changes": 9, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/7faf8d961df7559fb440fae757f2cd5554f29fde/docs%2Fidentity%2Fusers%2Flicensing-service-plan-reference.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/7faf8d961df7559fb440fae757f2cd5554f29fde/docs%2Fidentity%2Fusers%2Flicensing-service-plan-reference.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Fusers%2Flicensing-service-plan-reference.md?ref=7faf8d961df7559fb440fae757f2cd5554f29fde", "patch": "@@ -8,8 +8,8 @@ manager: femila\n ms.service: entra-id\n ms.subservice: users\n ms.topic: reference\n-ms.date: 07/23/2025\n-ms.author: nicholak\n+ms.date: 10/29/2025\n+ms.author: shegu\n ms.reviewer: Nicholak-MS\n ms.custom: it-pro\n ms.collection: M365-identity-device-management\n@@ -27,7 +27,7 @@ When [managing licenses in the Azure portal](https://portal.azure.com/#blade/Mic\n - **Service plans included (friendly names)**: A list of service plans (friendly names) in the product that correspond to the string ID and GUID\n \n >[!NOTE]\n->This information was last updated on July 23, 2025.

ai_summary.Response: This commit updates several Microsoft Entra ID documentation files. It refines the analysis guidance for Microsoft Entra ID Protection, clarifies the process and recommendation for scrambling passwords to enable passwordless authentication, updates the administrator roles required for installing Microsoft Entra Connect Health agents, and adds new service plans related to Microsoft Entra Workload ID and Copilot for Microsoft 365 to the licensing reference.
